title: State v. Martinez - Insanity Defense Evaluation
question: Mental state at time of offense (insanity defense evaluation)
summary: Defendant with Bipolar I Disorder was in acute manic episode with psychotic features during alleged offense. Grandiose delusions and command hallauditory hallucinations present. Had stopped medication 2 months prior. Opinion supports insanity defense under M'Naghten standard - lacked substantial capacity to appreciate wrongfulness of conduct due to psychotic symptoms.

documents.description: Comprehensive forensic psychiatric evaluation for insanity defense
Analysis of defendant's statements to police showing disorganized thinking and delusional content

key_findings: Bipolar I Disorder, Most Recent Episode Manic with Psychotic Features (acute phase during offense)
Grandiose delusions (believed chosen by God to deliver message)
Command auditory hallucinations directing behavior during offense
Two-month medication non-compliance prior to offense - previously stable on lithium and olanzapine
Opinion supports insanity defense - lacked capacity to appreciate wrongfulness due to psychotic symptoms
Prognosis good with medication reinitiation - currently responding to treatment
